title: Understanding Endometrial Cancer
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value: Endometriosis is a condition where tissue similar to the lining of the uterus (the endometrium) grows outside the uterus.

content.title: Important
content.description: Endometriosis is a non-cancerous condition, but it can cause significant pain and may affect fertility.

content.value: The exact cause of endometriosis is not fully understood. Several factors are thought to play a role:

items.title: Retrograde (backward) menstruation
items.description: Menstrual blood flows back through the fallopian tubes into the pelvis

items.title: Immune system differences
items.description: The body may not clear misplaced endometrial-like cells effectively

items.title: Hormonal influences
items.description: Endometriosis tissue responds to hormones such as oestrogen

content.title: Did You Know?
content.description: Endometriosis is likely caused by a combination of these factors rather than a single cause.

content.value: Endometriosis can affect different aspects of life. Understanding its impact can help guide treatment and support.

content.title: Fertility Impact
content.description: Endometriosis can make it more difficult to become pregnant, particularly in moderate to severe cases. However, many people with endometriosis do conceive, either naturally or with medical support. Early assessment and appropriate treatment may help preserve fertility options.

content.title: Emotional Wellbeing
content.description: Living with chronic pain and fertility concerns can affect emotional wellbeing and quality of life. Seeking medical advice, pain management, and emotional support can help manage both physical and psychological effects.

content.value: Endometriosis can cause a range of symptoms, which often worsen around your period.

items: Painful periods – cramps that are severe, long-lasting, or worsening over time
Pelvic pain – pain between periods or chronic pelvic discomfort
Pain when urinating – especially during menstruation
Pain during bowel movements – often worse during periods

content.title: Important
content.description: Period pain is common, but severe pain that interferes with daily life is not typical. If you have ongoing or worsening symptoms, seek medical advice. Early assessment can help manage symptoms and reduce the impact on your quality of life.

content.value: Endometriosis can be difficult to diagnose because symptoms may overlap with other conditions.

items.title: 1. Pelvic Examination
items.description: A pelvic exam may be done, but findings can be normal. It may help identify tenderness, nodules, or ovarian cysts.

items.title: 2. Imaging Tests
items.description: Ultrasound (often transvaginal) or MRI can help detect ovarian endometriosis (endometriomas) or deep disease, but scans may not detect all types of endometriosis.

items.title: 3. Laparoscopy
items.description: A keyhole surgical procedure that allows doctors to look inside the pelvis. This can confirm the diagnosis and allow treatment or biopsy at the same time. It is usually considered when symptoms are significant or imaging is unclear.

content.value: Treatment is tailored to your symptoms, severity of disease, and future fertility plans.

items.title: Pain Relief Medication
items.description: Painkillers such as paracetamol or anti-inflammatory medicines (e.g., ibuprofen) are often used to help manage pain. These treat symptoms but do not treat the underlying condition.

items.title: Hormone Therapy
items.description: Hormonal treatments can reduce or suppress endometriosis activity. Options may include combined hormonal contraceptives, progestogen-only treatments, or GnRH analogues. These aim to control symptoms rather than cure the condition.

items.title: Conservative Surgery
items.description: Keyhole (laparoscopic) surgery may be offered to remove or destroy endometriosis tissue while preserving the uterus and ovaries. Surgery can improve pain and may help fertility in some cases, though symptoms can return.

items.title: Hysterectomy
items.description: Removal of the uterus may be considered for severe symptoms when other treatments have not worked and pregnancy is not desired. It is not a guaranteed cure, especially if endometriosis is present outside the uterus.

content.title: Key Point
content.description: Treatment focuses on long-term symptom control and improving quality of life. Decisions are made together based on your symptoms, response to previous treatments, and personal goals.
